course.subject: MATH
course.name: Matrix Algebra and Applications
course.description: Systems of linear equations; vector spaces; linear transformations; matrix representation of linear transformations; linear operators, eigenvalues and eigenvectors; similarity invariants and canonical forms.
course.prerequisites: A passing grade in AL Pure Mathematics / AL Applied Mathematics; OR MATH 1014 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1024
course.exclusions: MATH 2121, MATH 2131, MATH 2350

reviews.author: 神月 godmoon
reviews.title: Don't give up
reviews.comment_content:
Students who have prior knowledge of M2 /AL will have a huge edge. To those who haven't, no worries, the professor will teach everything from scratch.

1. Systems of Linear Equations
2. Linear Independence（New topic, but one of the most important topic）
3. Matrix Algebra and Determinants

4.*******Vector Spaces **********
Vector Spaces and Subspaces
Null Spaces, Column Spaces, and Linear Transformations
Linearly Independent Sets and Bases
Coordinate Systems;
Dimension of a Vector Space and Rank of a Matrix

5. Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
The Characteristic Equation
Diagonalization;
Applications to Dynamical Systems

6.***********Inner Product Spaces ***********
（Orthogonal sets, final boss.）
Inner Product, Length, and Orthogonality
Orthogonal Sets
Orthogonal Projections
The Gram-Schmidt Process
Least-Squares Problems
Applications to Linear Models （I think this must appear in every semester...）

I strongly suggest everyone take COMP2711/Comp2711H/MATH2033 before studying MATH2111. In this course, there are a lot of symbols such as, set, subset, ring, etc，我上完都唔太get啲symbol用嚟做咩， Professor又冇重頭講，另外呢個course都幾重視prove，畢竟linear algebra 幾抽象。
reviews.comment_teaching:
As there is only one class in the summer session, I have no idea if the professor teaches well. 加上year1走曬啲數堂，但佢嘅語速真係好好好好慢. Professor also responds to emails quickly, and is more than happy to teach you after class.

You can also learn from other sources such as MIT, Youtube, etc if you think the professor's teaching is bad.

I strongly suggest you do the exercises on Classviva, especially the True or False questions, in order to consolidate your concept.

The tutorial notes from TA are so good. The questions are challenging. I suggest you read the tutorial notes before clicking into the zoom meeting replay.
reviews.comment_grading:
The exam is terribly hard and unreasonably long. Maybe it is designed for online exams exclusively.

The Gram-Schmidt Process Least-Squares Problems and vector space， More time is needed in this part
Grading Scheme:
WebWork: 25%
Final Exam:75%

Final Exam Information:
Mean = 33.2 out of 72
S.D. = 15.3 out of 72
Median = 31 out of 72

Mine 63/72
Higher than 2SD
Final Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: 4 webworks, 80 questions in total for this semester.

reviews.author: luca590
reviews.title: Lectures and tutorial sessions totally useless, just go on Youtube
reviews.comment_content: Content is pretty easy and linear algebra is quite a useful subject. The lecture slides are also quite good as they go over everything needed and explain reasonably well, just the teaching is poor, I think especially for international students. The TA, Serena, speaks english natively, but she doesn't seem to take being TA very seriously and doesn't explain much in the tutorials, just repeats the answers (which are given out beforehand). It seems like she just, generally speaking, isn't good at math.
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof is nice, but a pretty bad teacher. He does not explain things conceptually, just teaches theorems and corollaries. Totally unintuitive and useless. Here is a really good series though on Youtube -> https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uQhTuRlWMxw&index=8&list=PLZHQObOWTQDPD3MizzM2xVFitgF8hE_ab
reviews.comment_grading: Terrible. Barely grades conceptual understanding, just whether you got the right answer. Would recommend enrolling in a class that grades conceptual understanding, even if it's a bit harder, unless you're very good at repeatedly doing calculations by hand.
reviews.comment_workload: Not terrible workload. About medium. Webwork about once a week, sometimes every 2 weeks. Takes more than an hour if you solve everything without looking it up.

reviews.author: Tommy Li
reviews.comment_content:
A quite standard introduction to linear algebra. Although some of the proofs are taught during class, they would not be tested in the exams.

Topics included:
Chap 1 Systems of Linear Equations
Chaps 2 and 3  Matrix Algebra and Determinants
Chap 4  Vector Spaces
Chap 5  Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
Chap 6  Inner Product Spaces
Chap 7  Symmetric Matrices and Quadratic Forms

Most of the content is extensions to DSE M2 topics. They are introduced a little bit more rigorously and additional concepts like abstract vector spaces are introduced.
reviews.comment_teaching:
It quite depends on whether her teaching style suits you. In terms of clarity and logical flow, she did a great job explaining everything clearly with suitable examples. However, if you are the kind of person who wants to learn more or an interactive fun lesson, you would not like her lectures.

Take myself as an example. I fell asleep in one (maybe more) of the lessons. I think I slept for ~45 mins, but I can easily catch up with the progress just by reading her notes and listening to her again. I can understand most of the content by attending lectures, but searching additional materials online may give you a better intuition of the subject.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading in this semester is much better than usual. You can refer to others' reviews for more stats. To be honest, I was shocked when I received the letter grade. I only got +0.7 sd in the midterm. I thought I'm screwed up when I received my final exam score. I know how to answer each question (which suggests high scores should be possible), and I get quite a number of them wrongly.

Midterm (30%): 87/100 (Mean: 74.68, SD: 16.85)
HW (10%): 100/100
Final (60%): 76/100 (Mean: 57.2, SD not released)
Overall: 81.2/100 => A

There is no paper checking for both midterm and final.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only regular webwork and no attendance taken like 1013 and 1014. Should not be a problem for most students.

The midterm is quite easy, so carefulness is more important than understanding the content. Practice more on past paper, and do more problems and you would be fine.

The final consists of only MC problems. Some of the questions are quite difficult. You need to be familiar with the concepts to get them correct. The annoying thing is there would be a 'none of the others' options so you will be doubtful whether your calculation is correct. Oppose to the midterm, the focus is on the concepts (especially on vector spaces). I believe you don't have to spend much time preparing but I do recommend you to watch this 3b1b series to have a visual understanding (instead of blindly remembering definitions).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fNk_zzaMoSs&list=PLZHQObOWTQDPD3MizzM2xVFitgF8hE_ab

reviews.author: ptrknow
reviews.title: Speed! Power! and Passion!
reviews.comment_content:
Very computational. But you don't need to know much to do the computation, because all the things are just based on row reduction (or Gaussian elimination), matrix algebra and determinant (with dot product as well).

Okay, the truth is, the course still introduces to you many theorems. Most of these are wordy, and at the end of the course, you still don't know their actual fucking use (the notes and the textbook just gave some brief explanation, or gave none at all).

Not to mention that you won't be able to do actual linear algebra proofs after taking this course. (Well, the proofs in exams are literally just another way of asking you to do computation.)

But isn't it good? Computation is easier than proofs afterall! Weeeeell... The problem is, what are needed to compute are just row reduction, matrix algebra and determinant (with dot product later)... The course reduces to doing these 3-4 things repeatedly throughout the 3-month period, which makes it very boring and unworthy of time.

Deemphasizing proofs like in MATH 2011 is acceptable, but more concepts should have been introduced and more explanation should have been given!
reviews.comment_teaching:
A powerpoint warrior: reading aloud the powerpoint with a monotonous tone.

你或許在中學聽過"PPT戰士"一詞。LEE先生以沉悶的語氣完美演繹了當中之精髓。
reviews.comment_grading:
MIDTERM
You may ask: what the fuck is wrong with my title?
To do the midterm, you need 3 things.
SPEED - Speed yourself fucking up, or else how would you be able to do 4-by-4 row reduction and determinant in a mere 75 minutes?
POWER - Power your brain so that you won't make a single minor mistake in solving the 4*4 matrix that can ruin your 20% mark.
PASSION - so that you won't give up in the midway doing the stupid paper....
It is not a test of intelligence, nor a test of understanding (well maybe you need some in doing the MC, but guessing them would be more efficient), but rather a test of time and speed. Ok, seriously, this is not Initial D, but a stupid midterm.
And one more thing, this semester the midterm is easier. But that would also mean you got to be more careful....

Format: 5mc + 4lq (row reduction, inverse, linear transformation, determinant) The matrices are mostly 4-by-4
Mean/sd: 75.7/16.2 (To score 1SD above, you can only afford losing 8 marks, or equivalently 2 MCs)

FINAL
The sample paper is even more torturing... 4*4 row reduction, matrix multiplication, finding determinant and inverse, Gram-schmit process, over and over again in 2.5 hr... I mean what the fuck?? The paper itself is not difficult, but very discouraging (disgusting) to be honest.

To everyone surprise, Mr. Lee was fired right before the final. So I guess the actual paper was written by Mr. Li. The style really differs a lot. Matrices became smaller, i.e. reduced to 2-by-2 or 3-by-3, but sadly there was one difficult long question about vector space.

Format: 10mc + 6lq
Mean: 60 something

GRADING
Not really know if the grade is good. Just give you some reference:
Midterm 92 + Final 81 -> A-
(Both should be around 1SD above mean)
reviews.comment_workload:
Official workload: 10 webworks only (difficulty varies)

Lectures and tutorials can be skipped. Self-study is a better option. Tutorial notes from Wang Jingjing are useful for revision.

reviews.author: Billy Ng
reviews.title: 唔算太難
reviews.comment_content:

Systems of Linear Equations

Vector Spaces

Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors

每一個課題都幾清晰,唯一就係Differential Equations要扣少少分
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Ho嘅上堂方法簡直冇得彈,唔會就咁講概念,會連埋例題一齊教你,而且例題嘅步驟好清晰,上堂miss咗都可以自己睇notes補番

reviews.comment_grading: 唔算好grade唔算爛grade,高mean零點幾都有B-
reviews.comment_workload:
開始嘅四個星期都ok,每兩個星期有一份webwork,但考完midterm之後情況特變,突然間變咗一個星期兩份,直至到考試

reviews.author: Troy
reviews.comment_content: 呢一個COURSE就係講一D MATRIX既野，如果有讀M2既話，應該有一半內容係學過哂。不過剩低果一半就比較難，要真係去理解，所以唔識真係要去問人，MATH SUPPORT CENTRE就係一個好好既地方
reviews.comment_teaching: 教我果個就教得唔係幾好，上堂成日係到講D唔多關事既MATH故仔，又教得唔清楚同成日提早落堂，所以去到SEM尾果陣都係得返五份一人會上佢堂
reviews.comment_grading: 我MIDTERM同FINAL都MEAN高1.5個SD，最後就攞左個A。同埋呢科個MEAN係MIDTERM同FINAL年年都係維持係五到六成分。
reviews.comment_workload: 同1013,1014一樣，都係MIDTERM,FINAL同ASSIGNMENT,所以都唔係好重WORKLOAD

reviews.author: An225 Mriya
reviews.title: All we have to do is to do Gaussian elimination at the right time!
reviews.comment_content:
Course contents includes:
*Linear systems#, elementary row operations#, row echelon forms#, Gaussian elimination#
*Linear combinations, span of vectors
*Matrix multiplication#
*Solvability theorem, solution structure of homogeneous and non-homogeneous linear systems#, linear independence and dependence
*Linear transformation, composition of linear transformations, one-to-one and onto linear transformations
*Matrix arthimetics, transpose of matrices#
*Invertible matrices#, determinants#, elementary matrices, Cramer's rule#, area and volume theorem#
----Midterm----
*Vector spaces and subspaces
*Null, column, row spaces
*Linear independent/dependent sets
*Bases for vectors, spanning set theorem
*Bases for null, column, row spaces
*Coordinate systems and mapping
*Dimensions, matrices of linear transformations
*Eigenvalues, eignevectors and diagonalization
*Inner products, length, orthogonal projection
*Orthogonal/orthonormal sets, orthogonal decomposition, Gram-Schmidt process

Topics with "#" means contents taught in DSE M2. As one can see, large amount of contents before the midterm are introduced in high-school-level M2. Students who've studied M2 also have the advantage on doing Gaussian elimination more quickly due to previous exercises.

The topic of diagonalization is also implicitly involved in your M2 curriculum. Think about of that type of long question where you were required to find the 100th or 2020th square of a certain matrix----that's part of the typical diagonalization problem, with the diagonalized matrix directly given to you.

In general, I find that MATH2111 one of the easiest MATH courses throughout your engineering program.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This year's lecturer is Dr. Ho. As I've reviewed his teaching style when I reviewed MATH2011, I'll leave the link to my previous review:

https://ust.space/review/MATH2011/view/z8z9U1U6UccMOSuXsJ5NELMI1YhiM8vd

This semester's TA is Tommy Cheng, who spoke a moderate Hong Kong accent. That said, his teaching was generally clear (if not a few careless mistakes), and he do provide us with ample after-class questions and true/false concept questions for us to revise. Extra questions were provided before the final exam, which is a plus for calculation-intensive courses.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme is similar to MATH2011:
9 assignments: 10% (All full marks)
2 presentations: 10% (All full marks)
Midterm: 30% (19/33, Mean: 18.34/33, SD 5.3)
Final: 50% (42/50, Mean: 29.45/45)

When compared with last year's MATH2011, the assignments and presentations are generally easy and straightforward, and the midterm and final questions are also the as well: there are neither complicated nor tricky questions.

Moreover, this year's midterm contains 1 long question lasted for 15 minutes, and the final have 2 for 15 and 10 minutes. Both are strikingly easy, but the limited time means any hesitation may lead you to 0 mark in the long questions. You should therefore ensure yourself familiar with all theorems. All other questions in the midterm and finals are MC questions.

For those who regularly skip courses, you are also advised to review course videos (well, if next semester still provide them). One long question during the midtetrm asked you about visualizing the concept of one-to-one and onto as taught on the lectures.

At the end, thanks to the improved final result, I get an A for this course, which is my first and last A range grade in a MATH course. This shows that with more practice before exams, it's not really hard to attain a A range or even A+ for MATH2111.
reviews.comment_workload:
The 9 assignments are similar to your typical MATH assignments, but this time some questions, especially conceptual T/F questions have limited attempts. It can be therefore observed that a number of students slumped thanks to this mechanism, as seen from the mean of some assignments that go as low as 74.89/100. All in all, if you have doubts when doing assignments, consider going to the Math Support Center for help.

Presentations are also easy and straightforward, something similar to last year's MATH2011. Perhaps due to anti-cheating during online semester, Professor Ho implements some additional requirements regarding our presentations. Follow all instructions (like some descriptions must be written on real paper) and you should get an easy full mark.

So similar to other MATH courses, the main workload comes from preparing the midterms and finals. Do past papers help, and the exam's difficulty should be also on par with the past papers.

reviews.author: B.T.
reviews.title: Good grade, not killer 明
reviews.comment_content:
Matrix Algebra

Topic 1: System of Linear Equations and Gaussian Elimination
- if u have studied M2 before, or u are good at solving system of equations, this part is just a piece of cake.
- if u are not familiar, make sure to spend some time to understand and be careful in solving equations, many topics afterwards will use this technique.

*Topic 2: Linear Transformation, Linear Independence, Span
- imo is more abstract, better go to the lecture and understand the examples in the slides and notes.

Topic 3: Determinants and Matrix Inverse and Transpose
- actually they are not difficult, memorise the steps to find matrix inverse will suffice.

{Midterm Exam}

*Topic 4: Vector Space, Subspace, Null Space, Column Space and their bases
- it is the most difficult yet takes up most of the exam percentage in the final. Make sure u spend MOST of the time understanding everything here. They are abstract and may not appear important initially, but indeed they are very critical for you to understand the remaining topics and to ace the final exam.

Topic 5: Eigenvalues, Eigenvectors, Diagonal Matrices
- Simple and straightforward, don’t be scared by the name. Memorise all the procedures to diagonalise a matrix is fine.

Topic 6: Inner Product Space (This sem due to insufficient time, we did not include the following: Orthogonality, Orthogonal Projection and its basis, Least-Squared Problems)
- cannot comment on this topic cuz this semester just used 1 lecture to cover, instead of 3 classes in previous semesters.

*Make sure u spend more time on understanding the topics with (*)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is good, clear and very logical and coherent. Tho something may be simplified instead of explaining in a so “mathematical manner”, this kind of teaching may be good for those students who like extensive proofs and mathematical terminologies.

Lecture notes are detailed and colorful, but may somehow be wordy. I suggest going to the lectures and complement the concepts taught with examples in notes rather than simply read the notes. It may be difficult to understand everything by just reading through the notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good grading.

I got 100.00% in everything, A+ as expected.

However, many other students claimed that above mean by not enough 1 s.d. still secure an A-range, and the mean score is quite low given the midterm and final exam are not so difficult at all. Mean for this semester around 75, getting about 80% overall is a B+, and someone got 85% overall resulted in a straight A.

Webwork 15% (Mean around 80% only, so make sure to do your WebWork and you will already beat a lot of students)
Midterm 30% (Mean 78%)
Final Exam 55% (Mean 72%)

Overall Course Mean 75.96, sd is 14
reviews.comment_workload:
8 Webwork throughout the term, each has around two weeks to complete.

Make sure to do the WebWork but not go copy from chegg since midterm and final exam questions are quite similar to what you have practiced on WebWork. So treat is as a way to understand and practice the lecture materials. Some MCQs on WebWork may have limited attempt around 5 chances, don’t wildly guess but read over the lecture slides, understand before doing.

For midterm and final exam, go to Peter Gao website and download 2-3 sets of past-paper (with solution), do them and check your answers, make sure to understand. After that, you will find exams are more or less the same as the past years, and you will secure your exam scores.

Be CAREFUL in solving matrices and systems of linear equations is also a key to succeed! Otherwise, you may waste a lot of time in solving equations. (especially for finding matrix inverses and diagonal matices)

reviews.comment_teaching: The lectures are boring as the professor does not explain the concepts properly. Tutorials are much better as the tutors explain the concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is harsh
10% - webwork
30% - midterm
60% - final
If you are slightly above mean, you will end up with a B+
reviews.comment_workload: Only webwork is there every week. Nothing else

reviews.author: Eclipse
reviews.comment_content:
Covers much of the required knowledge about matrices and their related spaces. Contents include:

- Gauss-Jordan Elimination
- Linear Dependence
- Vector Spaces
- Eigenvectors/Eigenvalues
- Orthonogality
- Inner Product Space

If you have done IB HL Maths or A-levels Further Maths, and scored decent for them, understanding the content wouldn't be very difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: Pretty informative - he makes all teaching on the whiteboard, which gives you ample time to jot down notes and digest the concept. He provides notes with detailed explanations and examples for further study.
reviews.comment_grading:
Could be harsh if one does not score well for the exams. The percentage break down is:

- 10% Homework (via WebWork)
- 30% Midterm
- 60% Final

I got 1 SD above mean for MT, and mean for Final, getting a B. I would say it is not the best course you want to take if you want good grades.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not super high, only have to complete a few homework through webwork system over the course of the term. The tutorials don't really take attendance, so if you happen to get a really bad TA, be my guest to not go for the tutorials. They give you tutorial worksheet via the email anyway. (You can get them from the website of your profs if needed be)

However, the content gets a lot more complicated after midterms, so if you don't really study, you can kinda end up like me, getting a B where you could have gotten B+ or A-. Purchasing the book they ask you to purchase and doing extra practice from the book can increase the workload, but will definitely help you get better grades.

reviews.author: gdhdsv
reviews.comment_content:
system of linear equation
euclidean space
linear transformation
orthogonality
determinant
eigenvector

90% of the course content are about matrices.
Basically you need to know basic matrix operations like basic matrix addition, multiplication, row operation before this course. Being good at DSE m2 matrices can definitely help. If you haven't studied DSE m2 or anything about matrix before, it can be very hard for you to catch up. I will recommend you to study some intro to matrices first.

Like in khan academy:
https://www.khanacademy.org/math/precalculus/x9e81a4f98389efdf:matrices

Knowing Vectors is also quite important.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is normal. I think professor's teaching is good for students with good foundation. His teaching sounds and looks math-rigorous. He basically only follows his own textbook/lecture notes to teach.
I think his own textbook is quite boring for engineering students. Not very intuitive. It doesn't have many graphs and pictures. It's black and white. More than 90% of it are formulas, matrices and words, unlike those colorful textbooks and Youtube math channels.  It takes time to digest the content inside the textbook.

But it is still readable. See the attachment.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is good I think.
7 hw, 20%, I got 19%
1 midterm, 30%, I got 28.5%
1 final, 50%, I got 45.5%
Overall 93% and I got A.

The grading is fair. And the course is not very competitive so the curve is quite average.
The exam is like hw. Thus, if you can do the hw by yourself and revise your hw, you can do good in exam and get good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
7 written hw and webwork in total.
HW questions are like textbook.
It takes time to understand the textbook examples to finish hw. But once you understand the textbook chapters, you can finish all the questions easily.

Of course, the hardest part is understanding the textbook.

1. Systems of Linear Equations

6. Matrix Operations

Textbook: Linear Algebra and its applications (5th edition) by David C.Lay

1. Linear Systems, Elementary Row Operations, Row Echelon Forms

3. Linear Combinations of Vectors in ℝ𝒏 , Spans of Vectors in R𝒏

10. One-to-One, Onto Linear Transformations
11. Invertible Transformations and Invertible Matrices
12. Determinants

She is also willing to answer students' questions after each lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Webwork (40%)
Final Exam (60%)

For this semester, absolute grading is not used to determine your final grade, score distribute is used instead.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fairly low as there are only 6 webworks and a final exam. However, you really need to revise the things learnt regularly otherwise you would be lost. So I would say studying on your own is the main workload of this course.

Systems of linear equations, Row reduction and echelon forms, Homogeneous linear systems  and  solution  structure,  Matrix  Transformations,  Matrix  operations,  Matrix Inverses
Elementary  Matrices,  Determinants  and  its  properties,  Cramer’s  Rule  and  inverse formula, Areas and Volumes, Vector Spaces and Subspaces, Subspaces associated with matrices, Linear Independent Sets and Bases, Coordinate Systems and dimension

reviews.author: cindychow
reviews.title: MATH2111
reviews.comment_content:
The concept of the course is quite abstract. And actually, online resources are useful for your understanding of the course.
YouTube playlist "The Essence of Linear Algebra" - 3Blue1Brown
"Linear Algebra" - Khan Academy
and they are recommended by the instructors too

But once you understand the concept, it is not a difficult course.

But, if you are taking this course in summer, it is in a tight schedule that you have to understand a bunch of concepts in a short period of time. Think twice before you decide to take in during summer.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This course uses interactive lecture notes (online) that provide a java applet for showing the concept which I find is quite helpful for understanding. And Dr. Ku teaching is fair enough.

The lecture explains abstract ideas, and the tutorial is filled with practical problems. Mr Lau is a really good TA that could answer your question and explain the problems well. He is really willing to help.
reviews.comment_grading:
Summer Assessment Scheme
Online Homework: 25%
Final Exam: 75%

Yes 75% for the final exam, make sure you are okay with that before you enrolled in this course in summer. On the bright side, 25% HW means you already have 25% for the grade.

Exam
Mean: 55.74, Median: 56.5,
Upper Quartile: 71.25, Lower Quartile: 39
reviews.comment_workload:
4 weeks of courses in summer, with 4 online homework sets, fair enough.

The course provides you with many other exercise problems you can do at home, such as tutorial exercises, textbook exercises, and no need to hand them in. However, you should at least try to finish the tutorial exercise provided to have enough practice for the exam. Same as other math courses, practice makes good grades.

reviews.author: Christian_Chow
reviews.title: Good linear algebra course
reviews.comment_content:
Take this course, if you need or want to have to these skills:
1. Solve any system of linear equations (m equations and n unknowns) and determine if it has no solutions, unique solution or infinitely many solutions and write the solution set in parametric vector form.
2. Matrix Operation and multiplication.
3. Determine if a given transformation is linear.
4. Determine if a given linear transformation is one-to-one (injective), or onto (surjective) or both (bijective).
5. Determine if a given set V is a vector space.
6. Determine if a given subset is a subspace of a vector space and find its dimension if so
7. Determine if a given set is a basis of a subspace?
8. Determine if a given matrix is invertible by using the Invertible Matrix Theorem to justify.
9. Tell the properties of transposes, inverses, and determinant.
10. Find the inverse of a given matrix if it is invertible.
11. Find the standard matrix of a linear transformation, including but not limited to geometric linear transformation of R^2 and R^3 and their composition.
12. Find the basis and the dimension of Nul A, Col A, Row A of a given matrix.
13. Find the rank of a matrix. (# of pivots in rref) (through rref or Rank-Nullity Theorem)
14. Find the dimension of a vector space. (# of freedom)
15. Given the vertices of a shape, find its area before or after any transformation.
16. Find the Ker(T) and Im(T) of a given linear transformation.
17. Diagonalize a matrix.
18. Determine if a given A is diagonalizable. Find A^n if A is diagonalizable.
19. Find eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a matrix and the eigenspace of an eigenvalue.
20. Use Cayley-Hamilton Theorem to use A^n and A^-1. (Use A to replace lambda at the final step of solving a characteristic equation)
21. Find the norm or length of a vector.
22. Use Orthogonal Decomposition Theorem to decompose any vector into a vector on a plane and a vector orthogonal to it.
23. Transform a linearly independent set into an orthogonal set through Gram-Schmidt process.
24. Apply Least-square method to find the best fit line of a given set of point or solve the linear equation with no solution.
25. Decouple and then solve a system of linear differential equations.
26. Find the shortest distance between a point in V and a vector subspace in V.
27. Find the angle between two vectors
28. Find the orthogonal complement to a subspace (the bases of w^prep)
29. Turning a recursive relation into an exact formula
30. solving a predator-prey model.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good professor.

Excellent TA. (H S Lau)
reviews.comment_grading:
I hope I can have a good ending!! I really give it my all to learn linear algebra.

Linear algebra is now in my arsenal to solve problems from now on.

Final: 68/100 2 big careless mistakes (only read half of the question and made a mistake in handling the signs thus lost near 20 marks) + random marking scheme

Webwork HW: Full

• Eigenvalues and eigenvectors

• Inner product and orthogonality

reviews.comment_teaching:
Acceptable, his English is ok, but I don't think he prepared for his lesson lol, he always stops when he is talking. Normally I turn the speed to 1.5x or even 2x.

I asked him one question before the final and he replied pretty fast, dk what will happen usually.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think is quite fair.

HW:25%
Final:75%

Mine: HW full, Final 53/60, originally can get 57/60 but some question i fked up, i wrote out the matrix and then forgot to find the dist, found the matrix and forgot to express in the way he wants, they don't provide any past paper so idk what they want, but anyways, I got an A, acceptable.
reviews.comment_workload: Only 4 HWs (i think is 4, anyways it is very less workload), unlimited attempts, not hard, TA will explain and even provide answers sometimes

reviews.author: Mison03
reviews.comment_content:
The content is quite similar to the M2 with some additional stuff.

Chap 1 Systems of Linear Equations ( M2 stuff )
(i) Systems of Linear Equations; (ii) Row Reduction and Echelon Forms; (iii) Vector Equations;(iv) The Matrix Equation ; (v) Solution Sets of Linear Systems; (vi) Linear Independence;(vii) Linear Transformations; (viii) The Matrix of a Linear Transformation.

Chaps 2 and 3  Matrix Algebra and Determinants
(i) Matrix Operations; (ii) Matrix Inverse; (iii) Characterizations of Invertible Matrices;(iv) Introduction to Determinants; (v) Properties of Determinants; (vi) Cramer's Rule, Volume, and Linear Transformations

Chap 4  Vector Spaces
(i) Vector Spaces and Subspaces; (ii) Null Spaces, Column Spaces, and Linear Transformations;(iii) Linearly Independent Sets and Bases; (iv) Coordinate Systems;(v) Dimension of a Vector Space and Rank of a Matrix.

Chap 5 Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors  (~4 hours)
(i) Eigenvectors and Eigenvalues; (ii) The Characteristic Equation; (iii) Diagonalization;(iv) Applications to Dynamical Systems and Differential Equations.

Chap 6 Inner Product Spaces
(i) Inner Product, Length, and Orthogonality; (ii) Orthogonal Sets; (iii) Orthogonal Projections;(iv) The Gram-Schmidt Process; (v) Least-Squares Problems; (vi) Applications to Linear Models.

Chap 7 Symmetric Matrices and Quadratic Forms
(i) Diagonalization of Symmetric Matrices; (ii) Quadratic Forms and the Principal Axes Theorem.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is great. Detail enough.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is ok. Be careful with the content shown in class.
reviews.comment_workload: Homework, mid-term, final - homework is easy so you can earn full marks.

reviews.author: Dicaprio
reviews.title: Less Assignments in Summer!
reviews.comment_content:
Mostly HKDSE M2 stuff about matrix and vectors.

Vectors: (should be taught in MATH 1014 but the previous semester is too slow) Linear combination and span and Linear independence are new

Linear transformations : just matrix. injective, surjective and bijective linear transformations are new

Gaussian elimination: use online calculator to do this, nothing new

Determinants: Areas and volumes, nothing new
Vector Space: matrix, vectors, polynomials are all vector spaces, maybe new?

Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors: this is new

Inner product and orthogonality: dot product and cross product and projection and some other new things
reviews.comment_teaching:
MoWeFri 9am~12:20pm, so early so not many people real time. (~70 enrolled, only 20~30 in Zoom and 5~10 face-to-face)
only 1 break in between around 11am so it is quite exhausting. If you learnt it before, the first week is boring. He used 1 week to talk about addition and multiplication of matrix and haven't reached Gaussian elimination...

the TA and the professor don't talk about what they taught. So, tutorial and lecture teaches different things. Tutorials teaches faster than lectures because TA don't know professor will teach the MATH 1014 stuff.
reviews.comment_grading:
He said he will follow the absolute grading scheme of math department.
F < 40% < D < 50% < C's < 70% < B's < 85% < A's

25% Assignments x4
-WeBWork, (not classviva but similar. it's a webwork called “WeBWork”) ~20 questions per assignment, unlimited attempts. around 1 assignment per week. Tutorial may teach some of the questions.(because TA don't have so many tutorial notes)

75% Final exam
*NOT* in class time, 5 long questions, 30 minutes each. MUST scan and upload after each question. not too hard because you can use some very smart online calculators. (it also works when I enter some variables into the online calculators so you can solve basically everything with it)

Mean = 35.9 out of 60
Median = 40 out of 60
S.D. = 16.3 out of 60

My score:
Assignment: 25/25
Final exam: 51/60
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: Moderate workload. the assignments are easy and can be finished in 3 hours. Even if you don't know how to do, just wait until the TA teach you in the tutorial. You have unlimited attempts anyway so you can keep trial and error.

reviews.author: hayward
reviews.comment_content:
system of linear equation
Euclidean space
linear transformation
orthogonality
determinant
eigenvector

the content differs from high school as it provides the geometrical meaning of matrix applications and introduces a new concept called eigenvector. there is a different method to compute orthogonal projection which is more simpler and easier to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is quite good, but the progress is slow for you if you have previously learned matrices in high school. The tutorial class taught concepts clearly and thus attending it is preferred. I think attending lectures is optional as there are more resources online that teach more efficiently.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading is similar to other math courses.
75% final exam
25% WebWork asm

I got 55/60 in the final and
a full score on the homework assignments.
the final grade has not been released but it should probably be an A using absolute grading

the questions can be done easily if you have done all the past papers in other semesters.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is small relative to other courses with only online math assignments and an optional amount of self-practices. The last assignment might be difficult but after doing it you will realize that revision is needed and try hard to practice to finish the homework quicker.

reviews.author: RIPME
reviews.title: Memorizing, memorizing,...
reviews.comment_content:
Chap 1            Systems of Linear Equations  (~10 hours)
(i) Systems of Linear Equations; (ii) Row Reduction and Echelon Forms; (iii) Vector Equations;
(iv) The Matrix Equation ; (v) Solution Sets of Linear Systems; (vi) Linear Independence;
(vii) Linear Transformations; (viii) The Matrix of a Linear Transformation.

Chaps 2 and 3            Matrix Algebra and Determinants  (~8 hours)

(iv) Introduction to Determinants; (v) Properties of Determinants;

Chap 4                        Vector Spaces  (~6 hours)
(i) Vector Spaces and Subspaces; (ii) Null Spaces, Column Spaces, and Linear Transformations;
(iii) Linearly Independent Sets and Bases; (iv) Coordinate Systems;

Chap 5                        Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors  (~4 hours)

(iv) The Gram-Schmidt Process; (v) Least-Squares Problems; (vi) Applications to Linear Models.

Chap 7                        Symmetric Matrices and Quadratic Forms  (~2 hours)
(i) Diagonalization of Symmetric Matrices;

There are incredibly a lot of definitions to remember. Approximately 30 before midterm and totaling up to 70 for final. Although most of the definitions are quite intuitive, it is important to note down the tricky ones. The calculation part is pretty simple.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. Ye teaches slowly and clearly. Her handwritten lecture notes are easy to read and review. She provides some examples which are helpful for doing homework and preparing for exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
Normal grading.
10%  Online Webwork Exercises
30%  Mid-term Test Mean = 68.17 SD = 14.85 (L2)
60%  Final Examination: Mean = 63.82 SD = 18.14 (L2)

reviews.author: 69verynice
reviews.title: GRADE DISTRUBUTION INCLUDED HERE!! How could there be two totally different system in one course?
reviews.comment_content: Extension of M2 stuff, not going to repeat the same thing from others.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecture: His teaching style does not fit me, He explains logic in an abstract way, then follow with vague examples. He uses the same system for the first half of the course, which only covered part of the story. Lecture notes are not the most organize as well. So it is not so helpful. To be honest I would rather learn the operation before learning the concept and logic behind. He prefer face to face only class so expect him to not offer zoom class if there is no NIHK student in your class.

Tutorial: My tutor is Fan Junyi. He explains key concept with practical example in every tutorial, helpful TA!

If you find the content in this course hard, find Khan Academy on YouTube, his video on linear algebra and vector space are clear and helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are two grading system in this course, two instructors use their own grading system instead of a standard one. Only Prof Yan class have written HW. Webwork questions and exam questions are both different for two profs' class, so as the grading. In our class, only 3 chances are given to each webwork question, while the other classes got infinite chances.

20% Homework: Both written and WebWork homework will be assigned. I got 90.95% in written and 86.81 in webwork.

30% Midterm, I got 87%

50% Final, I got 83%
Overall course score is 85.58, got a B+ at the end. As you can see the score is higher in Prof Yan's class(aka harder to get high grade), not sure if it is because student in our class are smarter, exam paper are easier or what.

Prof Yan 'generously' released the PDF file containing the course grade with the score of all HW and exams of the whole class(with name and ID)to all of us. Not going to show the PDF due to obvious reason, but below is the range of different grades according to the PDF. The score below are all overall course score.

A+ >=99.21
A 91.04~97.87
A- 88.47~90.24
B+ 82.2~87.57
B 72.4~81.67
B- 66.59~71.22
C+ 63.04~65.76
C 56.15~61.91
C- 50.18~53.25
D 46.66~47.37
F <44.87
reviews.comment_workload: Not so heavy. 7 Webworks and 7 written HW in total. Usually one webwork ad one written are assigned together, sometimes two webworks with one written. Homework were assigned around every 2 weeks(in summary 2 to 3 pieces of hw per 2 weeks in total), each piece of hw take 1 to 2 hours to finish.

reviews.author: Jasa

The most difficult is MC concept questions, which need to pay some extra effort.

Basically what others mentioned.
If you have taken DSE M2, the content before midterm is easy and you can get above mean by briefly revising the lecture notes and doing some past papers.
When it comes to final exam, do as many past papers and exercises as you can and you are guaranteed B+.

reviews.comment_workload:
Not heavy. Webwork HW every week. Some questions are conceptual and they are not unlimited attempts. You can hardly google the answers and many people lose marks on those. Think twice before you submit the answers.
Conceptual questions are a big part in the exam. They are quite tricky and account for many marks, so make sure you understand the concept.

reviews.author: McNuggets
reviews.title: Good grading course
reviews.comment_content:
Some topics are deleted comparing to MATH2121.

Chap 1. Systems of Linear Equations  (~10 hours)
Chaps 2 and 3. Matrix Algebra and Determinants  (~8 hours)
Chap 4. Vector Spaces  (~6 hours)
Chap 5. Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors  (~4 hours)
Chap 6. Inner Product Spaces  (~6 hours)
Chap 7. Symmetric Matrices and Quadratic Forms  (~2 hours)

The content is not so hard, only if you pay enough efforts. Every time when the lecture is just over, you may feel confused since there are so many new concepts. But sometimes the new concepts are actually referring to previous materials. Revise the lecture notes for several times and try to find the connections among topics, things will be easier.

But as others said before, I don't think this course will let you form a clear and comprehensive mindset for linear algebra. Just learning how to solve the test questions.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor YE is a nice person. Most of the students feel unsatisfied with her accent, but I think it's acceptable. When coming to a new concept, she tries her best to connect it to previous topics, which is helpful for me.
Her lecture notes are decent and clear. Also she is always willing to answer your questions, no matter it's during the lecture, right after the lecture or via emails.
reviews.comment_grading:
Same as I heard before, Professor YE gives good grades.
10%  Online Webwork Exercises
30%  Mid-term Test
60%  Final Examination

My marks:
Webwork exercise: 99.78/100
Midterm: 85/100 (mean: 64.14)
Final: 89/100 (mean: 63.09)
Overall: 88.87/100 (mean: 66.1)
Grade: A

Not that hard to get high grades if you revise the lecture notes carefully, since the test questions don't require you to prove anything. Just solve them as the lecture notes do.
With overall 85+ you can get an A, probably 92+ for an A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not so heavy, just 10 homework on WebWork for the whole semester. I spent about 1-2 hours on each homework. Some true or false questions are tricky, but for most of the questions you have infinite times for trial, so not a big deal. However I think most of the questions are useless for both preparing exams and consolidating your knowledge. I suggest you spend more time on the textbook exercises which are available on ClassViva.
For me, actually most of workload came from summarizing the notes. The content isn't so hard, but the lectures progress quite fast. For times I couldn't keep up with the content in the lecture since I wandered a little bit. So after lectures I spent quite much time on summarizing professor's lecture notes and the example questions inside them. Helpful indeed.

reviews.author: Apricity
reviews.comment_content: Same as other sections. Compared with 2121 or 2131, the content doesn't include that much.
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite boring. I skipped most of the lectures, and I watched YouTube videos instead. The lecture notes and classviva could also help.
reviews.comment_grading: Bad grading. My overall score is 80 and mean is 68 for my session. End up with a B+. She likes concept questions so much. In the sample paper provided, almost all the questions are about concept.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite light workload. The most unpleasant thing is that you need to spend a lot of time to understand and practice the concept questions.

reviews.author: 夢想
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1) System of Linear Equations: Gauss elimination, row operation, row echelon form, existence and uniqueness, rank.

2) Euclidean Space: Euclidean vector, dot product, subspace, linear independence, dimension, basis of Euclidean space.

3) Linear Transformation: Matrix of transformation, matrix operation, range and kernel, inverse.

4) Orthogonality: Orthogonal basis, Gram-Schmidt, QR decomposition, orthogonal projection, least square.

5) Determinant: Volume, orientation, geometric property, algebraic definition, cofactor expansion.

6) Eigenvector: Eigenvalue, eigenvector, diagonalisation, symmetric matrix, quadratic form, singular value decomposition.

All the chapters are from the prof's own lecture note.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Wouldn't say that the teaching was good, but not that bad also.
This semester because of the mixed-mode, the teaching was divided into 2 parts: the first one and half months via zoom (as to wait for everyone to come physically to campus (HK)), and the rest of the semester via whiteboard.
For me personally, the zoom teaching is much better than the whiteboard as the writings are clearer and the recordings are much much better (ofc), although I think the prof might think the other way.
Prof will come up to your table if you have questions.

The TAs are good, sometimes he will show how to do the written homework questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% Homework: Both written and WebWork homework. Written homework questions are taken from the prof's lecture note.

30% Midterm

50% Final

Like the previous post, the TA will grade the written homework based on correct answers, so try not to do careless mistakes.
reviews.comment_workload: Written and Webwork homework, about 2 weeks each. Sometimes the written homework can contain up to 15 questions. In total: 7 written HW, 7 WebWork HW. Each homework may take up to 3 hours of work.

reviews.comment_workload: The workload is about 2 weeks one assignment and each assignment has at least 3 hours of work. Try to manage your time well

reviews.author: rind
reviews.title: 特別嘅一個Sem
reviews.comment_content:
Linear Algebra
同M2嘅內容好相似，但學嘅時候你絕對會覺得DSE M2 syllabus根本係做得好差，所以當重新學過一樣野會比較好。

Textbook: Linear Algebra and its Application (5th edition)
如果你睇其他Comment會見到今個Sem個Content有啲唔同，佢分左幾個大topic黎教，同埋同書教嘅Flow有啲唔同，個人建議跟書會好啲因爲早啲學Gaussian Elimination嘅話前面好多問題都可以輕鬆解決，同埋書易睇明好多，我見佢啲Notes寫得好難睇同埋唔詳盡，呢個Sem我無上過堂，全部都係書自學。

書嘅話就係Cover ch1到ch6
ch1係講最基本嘅System of equations, linear transformation
ch2係basic matrix operation，同埋有講到前期最重要嘅Invertible Matrix Theorem，基本上將ch1同ch2所有concept大雜燴
ch3講Determinant同Cramer's Rule，M2有學過唔難
ch4會係成個Course最難嘅Vector Space，概念比較抽象，建議睇3B1B abstract vector space黎攞個概念，實際做題唔算太難
ch5係eigenvalue, eigenvector M2都成日solve diagonalization問題，成個Topic簡單，做題都係千篇一律咁做
ch6係dot product嘅延伸版，講一講orthogonal basis, projection, least square problem，書嘅解釋講得好好，基本上問題唔大，Concept可能難啲，但做題都係好公式化，練一練就OK
reviews.comment_teaching:
今年因為Online Semester嘅原因，所以Prof改用左第一次以Geogebra Class黎上堂，會多啲用Geometry形式黎教大家（佢話係比3B1B嘅Linear Algebra Series啟發，個人都覺得用Geometry學會好好多，但書都寫得唔錯），但佢就第一堂講野比較慢，我之後都走哂堂。
TA就應該教得唔錯嘅，我上一左堂就無上，但Tutorial Notes啲題目嘅答法都寫得幾好，值得一睇。

推薦各位學每個Concept之前睇左3B1B嘅Essence of Linear Algebra先，另外有個TheTrevTutor都講得OK
reviews.comment_grading:
今個Sem因為係Online Sem，所以直接開放所有Online Calculator同Wolframe Alpha，變相就係題目會考得深啲同埋少純計算，多左Proof嘅題目，而且每一題時間都係得20min做，非常短，一旦諗錯方向就GG，好似我就係前面啲送分題出左事，就無左一半分。

由於可能係第一個Sem咁樣教同埋出呢種題型嘅卷啦，所以比Grade都比得鬆手好多，我見有人踩Mean都有B，非常好Grade。

Me
25% HW: full
75% Exam : 56/72 (mean : 33.2, SD: 15.3)

高mean大約1.5SD，最後A，應該差好少有A+，但都算係咁。
reviews.comment_workload:
成個course我係後尾睇書自學嘅，大約兩個禮拜左右就學完，書入面嘅內容比較多係唔關呢個course事嘅，但睇哂之後會融會貫通，好建議睇埋啲Proof去了解多啲每樣野點黎。有時間要做下書後面嘅題目，單數題目已經非常夠做，我因為時間唔多所以無乜做到。

功課如果有上堂同Tutorial就好快做完，得四份功課。

reviews.author: Joris113
reviews.title: It is an ok course, but the explanation on some of the content is complicated
reviews.comment_content: The content is fairly easy, but most of the time his explanation is overcomplicated that you need some time to absorb. However, you are welcomed to ask any questions to the instructor and he will answer your questions. There are so many 5 minutes during the lecture, which is pretty good as you can take a rest and ask questions if you want to. For the tutorial, IMO you don't need to attend it as the TA is just teaching to use software to solve equations. You can solve the equations by hand.
reviews.comment_teaching: most of the time his explanation is overcomplicated that you need some time to absorb. However, once you understand the content it is pretty easy to complete the homework.
reviews.comment_grading:
IIRC it is 10% assignment, 30% midterm, and 60% final exam
There are webwork and written assignment
The midterm is 3 hours, not hard, so the curve is pretty high (mean is ~82)
The final exam is online because you know, during that time there was social unrest. So everyone got very high marks in the exam
My final grade was 85.57, which was only a B- D:
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light, even though there is a written assignment every week and a webwork assignment every 2 weeks, you can complete the assignment fairly quickly.

reviews.author: Kevin KAI
reviews.title: Boring and fast learning
reviews.comment_content:
The content is not very difficult to understand
If you have learnt M2 before, you will get access to half of the contents easily because it is based on the matrix knowledge.
For the another half, it is not easy for you to get totally understand in the class, you need to review.
The Most Important thing is : TOO MANY THEOREMS should be remembered.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very Boring but Logical
Because I take in Summer Term, so she rushed all the contents very fast and sometimes I cannot catch her.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is good!!!!
Based on two parts: HW and Finals
HW is not very difficult to do. We used Webwork. Be careful of the MC Questions. I think it was difficult and not easy to get it right. You have limited chances to try the MC Qs.
And also, Pay attention to the deadline of HW. The deadline of  HW in summer term is not regular. I missed some Questions due to that.
The final is easier than what I had thought. I get 92/100 of that.
Finally, I get an A
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not so big. It is very suitable to take in summer sem.
I think the largest workload of this course for me is revision. Because if you don't spend some time in reviewing the teaching material, you don't know how to do.

reviews.author: 芋頭
reviews.title: Difficult content but easy exam
reviews.comment_content: Vectors, Matrix, linear transformation, vector space, eigenvectors, derterminents, diagonalization, dot product, projection.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Quite fast and deep, many content exams not required.
Good English! Hard to follow for me though. Youtube video may be more helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
Webwork can help you get the concepts clear.
Only have to understand the basic calculation.
Midterm and final are easy and very similar to sample paper.
midterm 30% final 60% assignment 10%

midterm below mean 1 sd and final above mean one SD. B+

fair grading. Quite Good.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not heavy workload. The concepts are deep, but the exam is quite easy.
Tutorial somewhat helpful for slow learners.

reviews.author: Erika Aggarwal
reviews.comment_content: Systems of linear equations; vector spaces; linear transformations; matrix representation of linear transformations; linear operators, eigenvalues and eigenvectors; similarity invariants and canonical forms.
reviews.comment_teaching: The classes are very boring and monotonous. Nobody shows up for the 9am classes and he doesn't make the classes comfortable enough to ask questions. He teaches in a very robotic way not at all interactive. I didnt understand half of the things being taught in the class and had to refer to online videos and the textbook.
reviews.comment_grading:
The practice from the homeworks or the lectures isnt enough. I had to get the textbook to practice more questions which is very helpful to get thorough with the concepts.
1 midterm 30 %
10 webworks  10%
1 final 60%
The questions on the webwork are sometimes very difficult and difficult to do.
The midterm and the final was very similar to the sample paper so that was at least good.
The mean was low for both the papers so if you solve the questions in class and the sample paper you should be good for the exams.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload wasnt that high since no quizzes and no need to attend lectures. Tutorials are helpful to practice. Studying a week before the exam is good enough.

reviews.author: yh.hohoho
reviews.comment_content:
matrix from zero.
linear algebra introductory course.

week 1: Systems of linear equations, Row reduction and echelon forms, Homogeneous linear systems and solution structure, Matrix Transformations, Matrix operations, Matrix Inverses

week 3: Elementary Matrices, Determinants and its properties, Cramer’s Rule and inverse formula, Areas and Volumes, Vector Spaces and Subspaces, Subspaces associated with matrices, Linear Independent Sets and Bases, Coordinate Systems and dimension

week 5: Rank theorem, Eigenvectors, Eigenvalues and their applications, Homogeneous Systems of First Order Linear ODEs

week 7: Inner Product Spaces, Orthogonality and orthonormal sets, Orthogonal projections  

~ Gram-Schmidt process, Least square solutions and Applications （來不及教
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ho Hon Ming and Zeta, what else to expect
此生無憾（誤.

~ remember to attend lectures for his lecture notes
reviews.comment_grading:
pretty good I would say.

10% webwork
30% midterm
60% final

like most other ust courses
~ mean + 1 sd = A range
reviews.comment_workload:
趨近於零（誤.

total 6 webwork.
about one per week.
each has about 10 to 20+ questions; some with limited attempts.

reviews.author: Kenneth319
reviews.comment_content:
- Topics :
Chapter #1: Linear Equations in Linear Algebra: from 1.1 to 1.9
Chapter #2: Matrix Algebra: 2.1 - 2.3
Chapter #3: Determinants: 3.1 - 3.3
Chapter #4: Vector Spaces: 4.1 - 4.7
Chapter #5: Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors: 5.1 - 5.4
Chapter #6: Orthogonality and Least Squares: 6.1 - 6.5
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor is knowledgeable.
Although some time get bored
reviews.comment_grading:
Weighting:
10% weekly assignments.
30% midterm.
60% final.
As other math courses, attendance is not required.

Personally:
few points above mean resuit in B.
I got a SD above final & mean in midterm.
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly assignments, easy if you get close to lecture schedule. There is a little bit more studying when it comes to the final. practice wont disappoint u.

reviews.author: whoDis
reviews.title: Interesting
reviews.comment_content:
- Book Recommended by the Professor:
Linear Algebra and Its Applications 5th Edition by David C. Lay,‎ Steven R. Lay, and‎ Judi J. McDonald. You can find the book online.

- Topics covered:
Chapter #1: Linear Equations in Linear Algebra: from 1.1 to 1.9
Chapter #2: Matrix Algebra: 2.1 - 2.3
